g.title: Rectangle
g.desc: State (=Objects for States) Encapsulate state specific behavi...
g.text: State (=Objects for States)Encapsulate state specific behavior of an object in a separate class.

g.title: Rectangle.119
g.desc: The behavior of an object is dependent on its state, and must...
g.text: The behavior of an object is dependent on its state, and must change during runtime

g.title: Folded Corner.196
g.desc: The State design pattern compliments the Single Responsibilit...

g.text: The State design pattern compliments the Single Responsibility principle. It entails both the positive and negative side of the principle. In the State design pattern, each State has its own class. This has positive influence on many aspects (see ‘Why?’ section). However, it also has a negative impact on the readability/understandability, because the State logic is scattered throughout the code base making it more difficult to comprehend the ‘whole’. In contrast, a monolithic class that defines the state behavior in a centralized place, can be more understandable and readable. This statement can be debatable in case a state diagram is provided. The State pattern reflects the state diagram, but a monolithic implementation does not. Another disadvantage of the Pattern is categorized under the maintenance aspect. Each State Inherits from a common base class. This causes tight coupling between the concrete States. In case the State abstraction is extended, all States need to change. This problem can however be mitigated by implementing a default implementation in the State abstraction. In addition to the maintenance aspect, it generally requires more effort (time) and space (memory) when applying the State pattern.

g.title: Folded Corner.235
g.desc: The State pattern enables the possibility for an object to ch...

g.text: The State pattern enables the possibility for an object to change behavior during runtime. The State pattern provides this behavior via an OO approach. Each state of an object has its own class. The Context provides the interface towards the client and uses a State object to provide the State related behavior. The abstraction (=Context) is separated from the implementation (=States). This enables the possibility to switch the implementation of the Context during runtime. The implementation switching is accomplished via transitions. Transitions are triggered via a Stimulus. A Stimulus, for example, can be pressing the shutdown button on a PC. This Stimulus makes the PC transition from the ON to OFF State. In the OFF State the PC does not respond to any key press (except the power button). In the ON State the PC does respond to key presses. The PC shows different behavior based on the defined State. The transition logic can be implemented in the Context or in the defined States. In case State x with behavior x receives a Stimulus, it transitions to State y with behavior y. The State member of the Context is set to a different State object during the transition. The Context now behaves differently, according to the newly defined State.

g.title: Folded Corner.258
g.desc: The State pattern compliments the Single Responsibility by ‘l...

g.text: The State pattern compliments the Single Responsibility by ‘localizing’ each state into a separate class. This has positive impact on the maintainability, reusability, testability extendibility & stability. All aspects are compared against a monolithic state behavior implementation. Maintainability, because the state pattern provides explicitness. Explicitness is achieved via defining each state into a separate class instead of ‘hiding’ the state behavior in conditionals and attributes in a single class. This explicitness provides understandability, because the design (state-diagram) and/or real-world reflects the actual code. This enables developers to communicate, track down bugs and make changes more easily. I.e. a developer can derive from design or logging which State needs investigation, bug resolution or change. Developers are forced to view the code in a State-format, enabling identification of edge cases more easily (e.g. what should happen when State x fails in action y). Reusability, because state logic is distributed amongst different classes. In case the transition logic is located in the Context, then States can be reused across different Contexts. Testability, because each State, representing specific object behavior of a state, can be tested in isolation. This results in a smaller problem window, that enables finding issues ‘quicker’. Extendibility & stability, because a new state can be introduced via inheritance and developed stand-alone (i.e. separately from other States). The introduction of a new state has relative low impact in comparison to a monolithic state implementation, where we might need to introduce change in multiple operations to restrict or enable certain behavior and risk breaking code unrelated to the change. In case of the State pattern, the change in other State(s) is minimized to the transition logic. Readability is not listed, because it is debatable. On one hand the cyclomatic complexity decreases, but on the other hand the code becomes more scattered (by introducing a State class for each defined State), which in turn results in complexity.

g.title: Rectangle.261
g.desc: An object, whose behavior depends on its state, contains oper...
g.text: An object, whose behavior depends on its state, contains operations with ‘large’ (repetitive) conditional statements and attributes to coordinate this behavior

g.title: Folded Corner.265
g.desc: The State pattern provides a solution to decompose large cond...

g.text: The State pattern provides a solution to decompose large conditional statements and get rid of state variables. A ‘monolithic’ approach, to implementing state behavior, would be via conditionals and variables on multiple places within the Object. The State pattern partitions these conditionals in stand-alone objects. These objects encapsulate the respective behavior for each conditional (=State). This approach decreases cyclomatic complexity of the object, makes change or extension less risky and provides explicitness of the state behavior. In a monolithic approach: -> Each newly introduced State will add to the cyclomatic complexity of the object.->Each state specific change will impact the stability of the object, by potentially breaking other code unrelated to the change. ->The explicitness of state behavior is ‘hidden’ in the conditionals, that negatively impacts understanding.

g.title: Rectangle.271
g.desc: Amount of states are priorly unknown
g.text: Amount of states are priorly unknown
